title: Is it proper to use the singular 3rd person 'they' in academic and professional writing? - Quora

response.answer_text: In informal speech you often hear “they” used for a singular antecedent (e.g., “Hey — who left their coffee on my desk?”). While from a linguistics point of view, “they” has evolved in common speech in the direction of serving a singular antecedent, that is not the case for academic or professional writing, where “they” is expected to have a plural antecedent. In college English classes I taught, I would mark incorrect usage of “they” down, but not in a judgmental way. It’s just a matter of being clear who your audience is and what the standards and styles are for that language. Even in APA, the style for most doctoral work, “they” has some discussion. See for example Bias-free language which takes one view and Purdue OWL: Pronouns which is more standard. And I’ve seen plenty of colleges’ official publications over the years that use “they” to refer to singular antecedents. If you use words in a non-standard way, you may lose your audience’s understanding. Even if you define your usage well, you may raise questions in the minds of the audience. In some fields — like legal writing — clarity on pronouns and antecedents is critical. In fact, having written and edited a number of legalistic documents over the years as a college administrator, I usually tried to avoid pronouns as much as I possibly could. For example, I wouldn’t write, “The superintendent is responsible for producing an annual report. The college president will review that report and give feedback. He will present the report to the school board by …” Who is that “he” referring to? Sounds like the president, but colleges don’t have school boards and superintendents typically do. (Title vary of course.) Something that simple can and has caused confusion in contracts and agreements, due to lack of clarity on a pronoun’s antecedent. Often when people are thinking plural anyway, even when they choose a singular antecedent. “A man has choices he must make in life” is no more singular in _concept_ than “the male lion typically lives in his favored savanna habitat.” Those could easily be changed to “people have choices they must make in life” and “lions typically live in their favored savanna habitat.” In general, it’s easy to avoid the “they” problem by simple rewording to change the antecedent from singular to plural. Instead of “Each student must have their homework turned in by noon” just say “All students must have their homework turned in by noon.” That also helps you keep out of the awkward “his or her” or “his/her” constructions. My hunch is that over time “they” will become more accepted with a singular antecedent, but I would not use it that way now for professional or academic writing — and definitely not for anything legalistic. Here is a map of gender distinctions in various language that readers may find interesting: Feature 44A: Gender Distinctions in Independent Personal Pronouns.  PS Over the course of my life, split infinitives have gone from being taboo to being accepted in a number of cases, and the use of commas has decreased dramatically (I could have left out that preceding comma, by the way). The rule against split infinitives was a rather misplaced effort to force Latin grammar onto English. The decreasing use of commas is interesting. Commas indicate a slight pause and slightly falling tone (not as much of a fall as represented by a period, though). Is the changing use of commas just an aspect of writing change, or does it also reflect changes in spoken language — suprasegmental features (or prosody) like intonation, for example?

For academic writing, it was the custom to use ‘he,’ ‘his,’ and ‘him,’ throughout the text. Now we have reached the age of political correctness, this assumption that everyone is a man is considered unacceptable as being sexist. At one stage, it was thought acceptable to add a sentence in the introduction, explaining that “when the text refers to ‘he’ this is intended to mean ‘he or she,’ but in the interests of clarity, the original convention has been retained.” I don’t think you can get away with that now. Most writers use ‘they’ for informal writing, but for formal writing, it would be better to refer to a person of unspecified gender as ‘he or she’ or ‘s/he’ or ‘he/she’. But then you have to use ‘his or hers’ and ‘him or her’ and the whole text becomes dominated by unwieldy pronouns, which can be annoying to read. The best method is to rephrase the text so you are referring to groups of people rather than individuals: “doctors will give patients their medication,” rather than, “the doctor will give the patient his or her medication.” Alternatively, you can use examples featuring a specific person, so it is correct to specify the gender. “Sue found the education in her son’s school unacceptable, so she…” You might use the same examples throughout, for instance by using a fictional family, or use alternate male and female examples.
